Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 43341-01 
Regional–Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
March 2011 
 
 
 
Capacity Building for Implementing Private Sector-Led 
Integration in South Asia 
(Financed by the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under the 
Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

Head  I. Azis, Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI)

Team leader  G. Wignaraja, Principal Economist, OREI 
Team member  W. Paz, Senior Economics Officer, OREI  
   
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Promoting and sustaining mutual trade and economic cooperation is a key objective in 
South Asia. Since the signing of the South Asian Free Trade Area (SAFTA) agreement in 2004, 
some progress in regional trade integration has been made in South Asia, such as an enhanced 
SAFTA, accelerated trade liberalization, and ongoing discussions for expansion of SAFTA to 
services. Despite gradual economic reforms and preferential liberalization, intraregional trade in 
South Asia remains at 4.3% (2008)—making it one of the world’s least integrated regions. 
Furthermore, free trade agreement (FTA) activity is at an early stage, with little participation of 
least-developed countries (LDCs). To bolster regional integration there is a need to move 
beyond trade liberalization to identify specific behind-the-border impediments to integration in 
South Asia led by the private sector and improve the capacity of the private sector to facilitate 
such integration. 
 
2.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  aims  to  support  capacity  building  for  implementing 
integration in South Asia led by the private sector. The TA and its components have been 
developed based on a series of consultations with several South Asian chambers of commerce 
and governments during 2008–2009.1 South Asian chambers of commerce have expressed the 
need for the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and other development partners to further support 
integration in South Asia led by the private sector. A high-level conference was convened in 
New Delhi on 17–18 November 2009 on Harnessing Business Opportunities for South Asian 
Economic Integration.2 As a follow-up to this, it was also agreed that an ADB–Federation of 
Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry (FICCI) working group would be formed to assist in 
the implementation of this TA. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.3  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The private sector plays a crucial role in globalization through the vertical integration of 
production networks across countries, particularly in East Asia. Furthermore, private sector 
participation  has  catalyzed  integration  and  the  formation  of  economic  corridors  (e.g.,  the 
Business Forum for the Greater Mekong Subregion program). In South Asia, the private sector 
has  also  begun  to  support  the  integration  process  within  the  South  Asian  Association  for 
Regional Cooperation (SAARC) and other initiatives for institutional cooperation. In 1994, the 
SAARC Chamber of Commerce and Industry was established to promote private sector and 
regional trade and investment in the region by bringing together the national chambers of 
commerce and industry of SAARC countries under one umbrella organization. These chambers 
of commerce are involved in policy dialogues with their respective governments and at the 
regional  level  through  the  SAARC  Chamber  of  Commerce  and  Industry.  Chambers  of 
commerce in South Asia (and particularly the FICCI) could play an important role in enhancing 
regional integration through, among other things, their ability to influence government policy 
making, particularly policies that will help improve the investment climate in the region.  
 
                                                 
1  Including ADB Office of Regional Economic Integration missions on 16–17 October 2008 and 23 March 2009, both 
in Colombo, Sri Lanka, and 13–16 May 2009 in Singapore.   
2  Co-organized  by  the  Federation  of  Indian  Chambers  of  Commerce  and  Industry  (FICCI),  the  South  Asian 
Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) Secretariat, Government of India Ministry of External Affairs, and 
ADB, the conference brought together over 130 participants including several high-level government officials and 
private sector representatives from SAARC countries. The Indian external affairs minister, ADB’s managing 
director general, and the SAARC secretary general, among others, gave keynote addresses.  
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 15 November 2010.

2  
4.  While the FICCI in India and other bodies in Bangladesh and Sri Lanka are influencing 
policies, an initiative led by the private sector to promote South Asian integration is still at the 
nascent stage. Resource and capacity constraints affect business associations, particularly in 
smaller economies or LDCs such as Afghanistan and Bhutan. Businesses, particularly small 
and medium-sized enterprises, lack the knowledge and capacity to compete and benefit from 
regional integration. The private sector still faces numerous barriers to business expansion, 
including visa restrictions that impede business travel, nontariff measures that increase the cost 
to trade, and transport connectivity and infrastructure that make the cross-border transit of 
goods difficult—the same barriers to intraregional trade and economic development in South 
Asia. 
 
5.  The  TA,  which  forms  part  of  ADB’s  regional  cooperation  and  integration  strategy 
(particularly pillar 2 on trade and investments), will draw on ADB’s experience in supporting FTA 
and  trade  policy  capacity  building  for  developing  member  countries  (DMCs),4 knowledge 
outputs, 5  and  existing  institutional  links  with  DMCs,  subregional  entities,  and  regional 
development partners. Specifically, it will build upon the recommendations of the TA Study on 
Economic  Cooperation  Between  East  Asia  and  South  Asia,6 TA  on  Private  Sector-Led 
Integration and Free Trade Agreements in South Asia,7 and the ADB–FICCI issues paper on 
Key Proposals for Harnessing Business Opportunities in South Asia.8 
 
6.  The activities and focus areas of the TA will be discussed with the DMCs concerned, the 
SAARC Secretariat, and chambers of commerce in South Asia, and will be coordinated and 
linked to the extent possible with the activities of the Office of Regional Economic Integration 
(OREI) and regional cooperation and integration operations of ADB’s South Asia Department 
and Central and West Asia Department.9 ADB is expected to work closely with the FICCI and 
other South Asian chambers of commerce as an effective channel to support and participate in 
the official SAARC process.10 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The intended impact of the TA is strengthened private sector participation in the South 
Asian  integration  process.  The  envisaged  outcome  is  enhanced  institutional  and  human 
capacity to implement integration in South Asia led by the private sector. It will also provide

3
opportunities for the private sector to discuss and share experiences at the regional level for 
more effective public–private collaboration. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will identify and address the direct constraints facing the private sector and 
recommend priority policies and activities to enable them to participate in cross-border trade 
and investment. Major assumptions include the adoption of market-friendly trade policies by 
South Asian governments, strong political commitment, cooperation of private sector groups, 
and sufficient staff resources. Political, economic, and social crises are some of the risks. 
 
9.  Output 1: Technical proposals to implement integration in South Asia led by the 
private sector. The TA will develop technical proposals on several key issues concerning trade 
facilitation and other impediments to development and integration in South Asia led by the 
private sector. This component will draw on the ADB–FICCI issues paper on Key Proposals for 
Harnessing Business Opportunities in South Asia (footnote 8). This component will also support 
the development of new proposals as may be identified during the TA implementation. The 
additional proposals are expected to focus on promoting an inclusive integration agenda for 
LDCs and pan-Asian integration. Inputs for the draft proposals will be sought from chambers in 
South Asian countries by bringing them together in a technical workshop (see output 2). At least 
five technical proposals will be prepared and circulated to DMCs concerned.  
 
10.  Drawing on the ADB–FICCI issues paper, an ADB–FICCI working group has recently 
been formed to make the case for enhancing integration in South Asia led by the private sector. 
The working group comprises key representatives of national chambers of commerce and 
industry in South Asia and ADB. The SAARC Secretariat, the SAARC Chamber of Commerce, 
and government representatives are invited to participate in the meetings as required. The 
working group also works as a research and advocacy body to develop and advocate these 
proposals, prepare other issues papers, disseminate the findings through consultations with 
various stakeholders, and make presentations at relevant events. ADB plays a catalytic role by 
providing  partial  financing  to  selected  activities  of  the  working  group,  and  assisting  with 
technical inputs and disseminating working group outputs. 
 
11.  Output 2: A technical workshop and a conference to present and discuss the 
technical proposals. The technical proposals will be widely disseminated through various ADB 
websites, conferences, and other appropriate forums. At least one technical workshop and a 
high-level conference will be organized under the TA in 2011–2013 to bring together the private 
sector and government representatives to deliberate on specific policy issues and actions to 
stimulate closer South Asian integration mentioned in output 1. To the extent possible, this 
component will be implemented in collaboration and/or coordination with related activities of 
DMCs concerned, the SAARC Secretariat, chambers of commerce in South Asia, and ADB 
regional departments concerned. 
 
12.  The draft proposals will be presented in a technical workshop involving the private sector 
and government officials. The workshop will discuss the different proposals and develop an 
action plan. To promote ownership of these proposals, workshop participants will also continue 
policy dialogues in their respective countries parallel to the SAARC-level policy processes. 
Once the proposals are finalized, a high-level conference will be organized to bring together 
South Asian ministers, private sector representatives, and ADB to take forward the proposals 
into national policy discussions and future project activities.

4  
13.  Output  3:  A  training  program  for  South  Asia  private  sector  associations  or 
chambers of business. Linked to the technical proposals, the training program will cover trade 
policy tools and methods useful for mid-level analysts in business associations. This component 
will  build  on  OREI’s  FTA  policy  training  courses  (e.g.,  South  Asia  economic  integration: 
introduction to concept, tools, and methods conducted in May 2009). The course will involve a 
mix of formal presentations, case studies, simulation, and practical group exercises on using 
ADB’s  FTA  and  trade  indicators  databases.  OREI  will  manage  the  training  courses  in 
collaboration with regional partners as appropriate. Training will be conducted by ADB staff (and 
experts). 
 
14.  Output 4: SAARC-wide firm-level survey on residual impediments to integration 
led by the private sector. The TA will aim to design a questionnaire and survey methodology 
and work on the implementation of the survey. This will draw from the experience of ADB firm-
level surveys on the business impact of FTAs in East Asia.11 The survey will aim to initially cover 
around  300  firms  across  the  region  from  selected  priority  sectors,  and  conduct  in-depth 
interviews as needed. If appropriate, a regional survey firm will be engaged to assist ADB staff 
in conducting the regionwide survey. 
 
15.  Output  5:  Technical  and  software  infrastructure  support.  A  small  grant  will  be 
allocated for the purchase of equipment and software (at least two personal computers and one 
server with licensed software) to improve the capacity of chambers of commerce of LDCs in 
South  Asia.  This  will  enable  them  to  communicate  more  effectively,  promote  e-business, 
support the implementation of the TA (including to pilot test one of the technical proposals in 
output 1 or support gathering of data for output 4), and improve the access of South Asian 
recipients to ADB knowledge products and use of ADB integration and FTA databases.12 The 
equipment may be turned over to a selected agency or private sector association or chamber of 
commerce upon completion of the TA.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA will be financed with a grant from the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under 
the Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility,13 to be administered by 
ADB. The total cost of the TA is estimated at $680,000 equivalent which will cover remuneration, 
travel,  and  per  diems  for  international  and  national  consultants,  ADB  staff,  and  resource 
persons;  cost  of  surveys;  workshops  and/or  conferences  expenditures;  travel  costs  and 
subsistence allowances for selected DMC participants; publication of reports; communications; 
and miscellaneous expenses. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. Within ADB, OREI will implement the TA in 
collaboration with regional departments (i.e., South Asia Department and Central and West Asia 
Department) and other offices (e.g., the Asian Development Bank Institute) to maximize synergy. 
ADB will work closely with DMCs concerned and the private sector, and in particular with South 
Asian chambers of commerce (e.g., FICCI) involved in previous OREI activities for South Asia. 
The focus areas and activities in relation to technical proposals, workshops or conferences, 
training programs, and firm-level surveys are expected to be developed in consultation with the 
                                                 
11 Survey component of: ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance for Free Trade Agreements in Asia: The Way Ahead. 
Manila. 
12 Such as the Asia Regional Integration Center; http://www.aric.adb.org 
13 Established by the Government of Japan.

5
DMCs concerned, SAARC Secretariat, and chambers of commerce in South Asia. To the extent 
possible, the activities of the TA will draw on good practices and experience of private sector 
associations and chambers of commerce in East Asia.  
 
18.  The  TA  will  require  approximately  4  person-months  of  international  (individual, 
intermittent)  and  40  person-months  of  national  (individual,  intermittent)  consulting  services. 
Around six international consultants are to be engaged, with varied expertise in economic policy 
analysis and business strategy. In addition, this TA will require 0.8 person-months (individual, 
intermittent) of international resource persons for the conferences and/or workshops to serve as 
discussants of the studies and technical proposals, prepare short papers as required, or deliver 
lectures for the TA’s training program. Two national consultants, including a trade economist 
and a project coordinator who will be based at ADB headquarters, will be engaged for 40 
person-months to ensure coordination and consolidation of findings and recommendations of 
the different outputs and trainings and to ensure effective TA implementation. The individual 
consultants  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
19.  Consulting requirements also include a surveying firm to be engaged for 3 person-
months to conduct an enterprise-level survey (output 4). The firm will be selected under least-
cost  selection.  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for  consultants  and  resource  persons  is  in 
Appendix 3. 
 
20.  At least two personal computers and one server with licensed software will be procured 
in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). The 
equipment will be purchased through the Procurement and Contracts Administration Section of 
ADB’s Office of Administrative Services and will be assigned to private sector organizations or 
chambers of commerce based in LDCs as may be determined by ADB. Upon TA completion, 
the equipment will be turned over to the user or users in accordance with ADB’s Procurement 
Guidelines. A no-objection letter will be obtained prior to the commencement or financing of any 
undertaking in the territory of any country covered in this TA. The TA will be disbursed in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time).  
 
21.  The  TA’s  implementation  will  be  monitored  by  ADB  through  regular  submission  of 
outputs from consultants and conference and/or workshop participants. The TA’s outputs, good 
practices, and lessons learned will be disseminated through ADB and Asia Regional Integration 
Center websites,14 presented at regional and national forums, and published as international 
reports.  
 
22.  The TA is expected to run for 36 months, from April 2011 to March 2014. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $680,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under the Regional Cooperation and 
Integration Financing Partnership Facility for Capacity Building for Implementing Private Sector-
Led Integration in South Asia, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Trade Economists and/or Trade Policy Experts (4 person-months, individual, 
intermittent) 
1.  The trade policy experts will have experience in visa exemption schemes for business, 
trade and transit agreements including a regional motor vehicular agreement, transparency and 
monitoring of residual nontariff measures, holiday schedule harmonization, harmonization and/or 
mutual recognition of standards and use of information and communication technology in customs 
stations,  promoting  intraregional  investment,  inclusive  integration  agenda  for  least-developed 
countries, or pan-Asian integration. 
2.  The  experts  will  preferably  have  an  advanced  university  degree  (master’s  degree  or 
equivalent) in economics, law, business, or related field; extensive expertise in trade policies in any 
of the areas given in para. 1 and familiarity with regional trends and cross-border activities in South 
Asia; and extensive research and policy analysis experience. They will develop technical proposals 
for implementing integration in specific areas led by the private sector. Under the supervision of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB), the experts will 
(i)  consult  with  ADB’s  Office  of  Regional  Economic  Integration  and  regional 
departments concerned, developing member countries, private sector organizations, 
ADB–Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry working group, and 
other stakeholders in South Asia on the needs and practical and coordinated action 
plan on the specific focus areas; 
(ii)  prepare a detailed outline of the proposal; 
(iii)  conduct a survey of literature and good practices in other regions and consolidate 
inputs from existing policy papers; 
(iv)  write a detailed technical proposal and revise subsequent comments from ADB and 
stakeholders; 
(v)  prepare executive summaries of the proposal, as required; and 
(vi)  make presentations in workshops or conferences, as required. 
 
2.  Survey Expert (3 person-months, firm, intermittent) 
3.  A survey firm, whether it is an academic institution, research center, or consulting company, 
will be engaged to assist ADB staff in conducting a regionwide firm survey of at least 300 firms in 
South Asia on the challenges and opportunities for business in a regional integration context. The 
survey may be designed in collaboration with the engaged agency or autonomously by ADB. The 
engaged  firm  will  assist  in  preparing  the  sample  for  the  survey,  conducting  interviews,  and 
preparing reports summarizing the results of the surveys. The consultant will also organize in-depth 
interviews for ADB staff and consultants on selected firms, if needed.  
B.  International Resource Persons (0.8 person-months, individual, intermittent) 
4.  The technical assistance (TA) will require the services of a pool of resource persons and 
policy  experts  to  make  presentations  and/or  facilitate  discussions  during  conferences  and/or 
workshops for this TA. They will have recognized expertise in specific topics such as visa-free 
business travel, use of information and communication technology in customs agencies, transport 
transit agreements, mutual recognition of standards, business procedures, nontariff measures and 
least-developed country participation in regional integration and/or pan-Asian integration, and a 
business enabling environment. The resource persons can be from the public or private sector and 
international or regional organizations.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
C.  National Consultants 
1.  Trade Economist (20 person-months, individual, intermittent) 
5.  The trade economist should have a postgraduate degree in economics, law, public policy, 
or the equivalent, and he or she shall have substantial expertise in international trade and regional 
integration. Excellent coordination and communication skills and survey experience are required. 
The trade economist will work at ADB headquarters during TA implementation. Under the direct 
supervision of ADB, the trade economist will  
(i)  provide TA for developing technical proposals and designing regionwide surveys; 
(ii)  make presentations and/or deliver lectures at the training program, as required; 
(iii)  provide technical support to international consultants, ADB staff, and the ADB–
Federation  of  Indian  Chambers  of  Commerce  and  Industry  working  group  in 
implementing the TA, including organizing workshops and conferences as needed; 
(iv)  undertake quantitative analysis as required; and 
(v)  perform other tasks as may be assigned by ADB staff. 
 
2.  Project Coordinator (20 person-months, individual, intermittent) 
6.  The consultant will be responsible for overall TA administration. The consultant will have an 
academic background in economics, communications, business administration, or related fields, 
and possess strong analytical and communication skills. The consultant will also have relevant 
experience  in  similar  assignments  involving  the  preparation  and  coordination  of  reports  for 
international publication. Under the supervision of ADB staff, the consultant will  
(i)  maintain proper communication with consultants and resource persons involved in 
the TA; 
(ii)  ensure timely delivery of the studies, proposals, and outputs; 
(iii)  provide research assistance and review several documents and other papers as 
required; 
(iv)  organize workshops, trainings, and conferences; and 
(v)  perform other tasks as may be assigned by ADB staff.
